question: What is the focus and accreditation of the Department of Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: The focus of the Department of Computer Science at NTU is on combining internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. The department offers undergraduate and postgraduate courses designed to be industrially relevant, balancing theory and practice. Additionally, all undergraduate degrees are accredited by the British Computing Society (BCS) to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council.

Computer Science courses

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.']

This is achieved through high-quality, interdisciplinary work in advanced computer science topics, which involves collaboration with partners from academia and industry.

question: What are some career opportunities available to graduates with a BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
['Home

Courses

Computer Science

Computer Science

As the digital economy continues to grow, and new and increasingly powerful technologies emerge, computer science underpins more and more of modern life. At NTU, we’ll use industry projects and collaborative research to help you develop the skills and experience that employers are looking for.

Find your course

Open days are the perfect way to see what makes life and learning at NTU so special.

Book an open day

    - BSc (Hons)

    - BSc (Hons)', "Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Experian

ground_truth: Graduates with a BSc (Hons) in Computer Science from NTU have secured roles across various industries, including Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, Graduate Game Development and Programmer, Software Engineer, Cyber Security Analyst, and Product Consultant. They also work for companies such as Next Retail Ltd, Boots UK, Cisco Systems, Schlumberger, Experian, BT, Rockstar Games, Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd, American Express, and the UK Government.

question: What is the overarching research vision of the Computing and Informatics Research Centre (CIRC) and how does it relate to their work in advanced computer science topics?
contexts:
['Zoheir Ezziane
            
            
                
                Senior Lecturer
                
            
            
              
                
                    
                
            
            
                        
                
                    
                    School of Science & Technology

View all staff

Computer Science courses

If you’re just starting out and are passionate about working in computing and technology, our accredited undergraduate computing courses can help your get there.

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.']
ground_truth: The overarching research vision of the Computing and Informatics Research Centre (CIRC) is 'Enabling Digital Technology'. This vision relates to their work in advanced computer science topics by grounding it in high-quality, interdisciplinary research with expertise in these areas. The CIRC's research is delivered through four groups that collaborate with partners from both academia and industry.

question: What are the areas of focus for the Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group at the School of Science & Technology?
contexts:
['Centre for Computer Science and Informatics (CIRC)
        Harnessing enabling technologies ranging from machine learning, AI, and advanced display technologies, to intelligent sensors and robotics to drive advances for individuals and society.

Research groups

Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
        The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world.

Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA)
        This research group brings together academics researching in the areas of computational intelligence applications.

Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group (CCBI) 
        This research group is centred around brain research, mainly brain computer interfacing (BCI) including EEG hyper scanning, and body sensor networking (BCI).']
ground_truth: The Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group at the School of Science & Technology focuses on researching computational intelligence applications.

question: What is the role of the Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG) at NTU in safeguarding against cyber threats?
contexts:
["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

Find out more about our research

Our facilities

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]
ground_truth: The Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG) at NTU plays a dynamic and dedicated role in researching and implementing effective solutions to protect against cyber threats. As a team of seasoned professionals, they focus on safeguarding information systems from various forms of cyber attacks.

question: What role does industry support and work placements play in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: Industry support and work placements play a significant role in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU. Students have the opportunity to apply their learning through live industry briefs, research projects, and gain real-world experience with the help of industry veterans from various sectors such as Fujitsu Systems and the US Department of Homeland Security.

You'll get involved in industry projects and  research to develop skills and experience employers are looking for.", 'language': 'en', 'filename': 'https://www.ntu.ac.uk/course/computer-science'}]

question: What is the primary purpose of taking a virtual tour at Nottingham Trent University's (NTU) Computer Science Department?
contexts:
["Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student.", 'Department of Computer Science
        Welcome to the Computer Science Department at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Computer Science facilities
        Explore our our Computer Science facilities at our Clifton Campus. You can take a look at the outstanding lab facilities in our ISTeC building.

Take a virtual tour
        The NTU virtual tour is a great way to get to know our University from the comfort of your own home.

Supporting your success
        What makes life and learning at NTU so special? Discover just a few of the benefits and free services designed to enhance your student experience.

Search for a specific course

Order a prospectus

Book an open day

Learn about life in Nottingham

Chat to students or staff

Also in']
ground_truth: The primary purpose of taking a virtual tour at Nottingham Trent University's (NTU) Computer Science Department is to get to know the university and its facilities, including the outstanding lab facilities in their ISTeC building, from the comfort of one's own home.

question: What are some examples of external businesses and organisations that our department has industrial placement partnerships with?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Our department has over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv.

question: What role does industry support and work placements play in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: Industry support and work placements play a significant role in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU. Students have the opportunity to apply their learning through live industry briefs, research projects, and gain real-world experience with the help of industry veterans from various sectors such as Fujitsu Systems and the US Department of Homeland Security.

question: What is the significance of the British Computing Society's accreditation in relation to the undergraduate degrees offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: The British Computing Society (BCS) has accredited all of the undergraduate degrees offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. This accreditation signifies that the department's programs meet high standards in terms of curriculum content, teaching quality, and industry relevance, providing students with a recognized qualification that is valued by employers.

contexts:
['Centre for Computer Science and Informatics (CIRC)
        Harnessing enabling technologies ranging from machine learning, AI, and advanced display technologies, to intelligent sensors and robotics to drive advances for individuals and society.

Research groups

Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
        The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world.

Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA)
        This research group brings together academics researching in the areas of computational intelligence applications.

Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group (CCBI) 
        This research group is centred around brain research, mainly brain computer interfacing (BCI) including EEG hyper scanning, and body sensor networking (BCI).']

question: What benefits do students at NTU's Department of Computer Science have access to due to the state-of-the-art facilities?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

question: What opportunities does a BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at NTU offer for students to gain real-world experience and enhance their career prospects?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: A BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at NTU offers various opportunities for students to gain real-world experience and enhance their career prospects. These include work placements, live industry briefings, and research projects. Students can also benefit from the support of industry veterans across sectors such as Fujitsu Systems and the US Department of Homeland Security.

question: What is the overarching research vision of the Computing and Informatics Research Centre (CIRC), and how does it aim to drive advances for individuals and society?
contexts:
['Zoheir Ezziane
            
            
                
                Senior Lecturer
                
            
            
              
                
                    
                
            
            
                        
                
                    
                    School of Science & Technology

View all staff

Computer Science courses

If you’re just starting out and are passionate about working in computing and technology, our accredited undergraduate computing courses can help your get there.

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.', 'Centre for Computer Science and Informatics (CIRC)
        Harnessing enabling technologies ranging from machine learning, AI, and advanced display technologies, to intelligent sensors and robotics to drive advances for individuals and society.

Research groups

Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
        The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world.

Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA)
        This research group brings together academics researching in the areas of computational intelligence applications.

Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group (CCBI) 
        This research group is centred around brain research, mainly brain computer interfacing (BCI) including EEG hyper scanning, and body sensor networking (BCI).']
ground_truth: The overarching research vision of the Computing and Informatics Research Centre (CIRC) is 'Enabling Digital Technology'. It aims to drive advances for individuals and society by delivering high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics. The CIRC's research is delivered through four groups: Harnessing enabling technologies like machine learning, AI, intelligent sensors, and robotics; the Interactive Systems Research Group focusing on cognitive and physical rehabilitation technologies; the Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group exploring computational intelligence applications; and the Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group working on brain computer interfacing (BCI) and body sensor networking.

question: What role do external businesses and organizations play in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: External businesses and organizations play a crucial role in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution by providing industrial placement opportunities, collaborations, and funding. With over 200 industrial placement partners such as Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv, students gain practical experience in their fields of study. Additionally, research activities are supported by various sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security, and the EU, which contribute to a wide range of internationally recognized areas such as serious games, computational intelligence, and security.

question: What are some examples of external businesses and organisations that our department has industrial placement partnerships with?
contexts:

question: What types of state-of-the-art facilities can students expect to find at NTU's Clifton Campus for their Computer Science studies?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: Students studying Computer Science at NTU's Clifton Campus can expect to find a variety of state-of-the-art facilities, including a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security labs, as well as human-interactive technology labs. The campus is self-contained with all the necessary mod cons and equipment.

question: What role does research excellence play in the Department of Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: Research excellence plays a significant role in the Department of Computer Science at NTU, as it combines internationally important research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. The department's state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design are designed to provide students with the right conditions to succeed in their chosen fields.

question: What role does teaching and research synergy play in enhancing the strength and relevance of academic programs at institutions with over 200 industrial placement partners?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Teaching and research synergy plays a crucial role in enhancing the strength and relevance of academic programs, especially at institutions that have over 200 industrial placement partners. This collaboration with external businesses and organizations allows for practical applications of theoretical knowledge, exposure to real-world challenges, and opportunities for students to gain valuable industry experience through placements. It also facilitates the integration of current industry practices into academic curricula, ensuring that graduates are well-prepared to meet the demands of their future careers.

question: What is the role of the Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG) at NTU in safeguarding against cyber threats?
contexts:
["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

Find out more about our research

Our facilities

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]
ground_truth: The Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG) at NTU plays a dynamic and dedicated role in researching and implementing effective solutions to protect against cyber threats. As a team of seasoned professionals, they focus on safeguarding information systems from various forms of cyber attacks.

question: What role does teaching and research synergy play in enhancing the strength and relevance of academic programs at institutions with over 200 industrial placement partners?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Teaching and research synergy plays a crucial role in enhancing the strength and relevance of academic programs, especially at institutions that have over 200 industrial placement partners. This collaboration with external businesses and organizations allows for practical applications of theoretical knowledge, exposure to real-world challenges, and opportunities for students to gain valuable industry experience through placements. It also facilitates the integration of current industry practices into academic curricula, ensuring that graduates are well-prepared to meet the demands of their future careers.

question: What are the advantages of industry-focused courses in Computer Science for job applications?
contexts:
["Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student."]
ground_truth: Industry-focused courses in Computer Science provide several advantages for job applications, including standing out from other candidates due to their practical approach and relevance to real-world employers. Graduates of these programs are perceived as having a competitive edge because they have hands-on experience that is highly valued by companies. This focus on industry also prepares students for various roles such as Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, and more.

question: What is the focus of undergraduate courses offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: The focus of undergraduate courses offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU is to be industrially relevant, with a balanced mix of theory and practice. Additionally, all undergraduate degrees are accredited to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status.

question: What are some of the facilities and resources available at the Computer Science Department at NTU?
contexts:
['Department of Computer Science
        Welcome to the Computer Science Department at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Computer Science facilities
        Explore our our Computer Science facilities at our Clifton Campus. You can take a look at the outstanding lab facilities in our ISTeC building.

Take a virtual tour
        The NTU virtual tour is a great way to get to know our University from the comfort of your own home.

Supporting your success
        What makes life and learning at NTU so special? Discover just a few of the benefits and free services designed to enhance your student experience.

Search for a specific course

Order a prospectus

Book an open day

Learn about life in Nottingham

Chat to students or staff

Also in']
ground_truth: The Computer Science Department at NTU offers state-of-the-art lab facilities, including those found in the ISTeC building. Additionally, students can explore these facilities on our Clifton Campus and take a virtual tour of the university to get acquainted with its resources.

question: What are the advantages of industry-focused courses in Computer Science for job applications?
contexts:
["Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student."]
ground_truth: Industry-focused courses in Computer Science provide several advantages for job applications, including standing out from other candidates due to their practical approach and relevance to real-world employers. Graduates of these programs are perceived as having a competitive edge because they have hands-on experience that is highly valued by companies. This focus on industry also prepares students for various roles such as Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, and more.

question: What role does industry support and work placements play in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: Industry support and work placements play a significant role in enhancing career prospects for students studying Computer Science at NTU. Students have the opportunity to apply their learning through live industry briefs, research projects, and gain real-world experience with the help of industry veterans from various sectors such as Fujitsu Systems and the US Department of Homeland Security.

contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. Courses

Computer Science

As the digital economy continues to grow, and new and increasingly powerful technologies emerge, computer science underpins more and more of modern life. At NTU, we’ll use industry projects and collaborative research to help you develop the skills and experience that employers are looking for.

ground_truth: NTU offers various undergraduate and postgraduate computer science courses, including a Bachelor of Science (BSc) in Computer Science with specializations such as Games Technology and Artificial Intelligence. Additionally, there are Master of Science (MSc) programs available like Cloud and Enterprise Computing, Computer Science, and Computer Science with an emphasis on Artificial Intelligence.

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. question: What are some examples of industrial placement partners that contribute to the strength and relevance of our teaching and research?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Some examples of industrial placement partners that contribute to the strength and relevance of our teaching and research include Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv.

question: What types of state-of-the-art facilities can students expect to find at NTU's Clifton Campus for their Computer Science studies?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: Students studying Computer Science at NTU's Clifton Campus can expect to find a variety of state-of-the-art facilities, including a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security labs, as well as human-interactive technology labs. The campus is self-contained with all the necessary mod cons and equipment.

question: What are the benefits of enrolling in accredited undergraduate computing courses offered at the School of Science & Technology?
contexts:

Computer Science courses

If you’re just starting out and are passionate about working in computing and technology, our accredited undergraduate computing courses can help your get there.

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.']
ground_truth: Enrolling in accredited undergraduate computing courses offered at the School of Science & Technology can help you get started and passionate about working in computing and technology. question: What role do external businesses and organizations play in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: External businesses and organizations play a crucial role in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution by providing industrial placement opportunities, collaborations, and funding. With over 200 industrial placement partners such as Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv, students gain practical experience in their fields of study. Additionally, research activities are supported by various sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security, and the EU, which contribute to a wide range of internationally recognized areas such as serious games, computational intelligence, and security.

question: What are the advantages of industry-focused courses in Computer Science for job applications?
contexts:
["Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student."]
ground_truth: Industry-focused courses in Computer Science provide several advantages for job applications, including standing out from other candidates due to their practical approach and relevance to real-world employers. Graduates of these programs are perceived as having a competitive edge because they have hands-on experience that is highly valued by companies. This focus on industry also prepares students for various roles such as Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, and more.

question: What are some examples of external businesses and organisations that our department has industrial placement partnerships with?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Our department has over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv.

question: What percentage of NTU's research impact was assessed as world-leading or internationally excellent according to the Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021?
contexts:
["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

Find out more about our research

Our facilities

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]
ground_truth: 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed as either world-leading or internationally excellent according to the Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021.

question: What are some examples of external businesses and organisations that our department has industrial placement partnerships with?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: Our department has over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv.

question: What opportunities does a BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at NTU offer for students to gain real-world experience and enhance their career prospects?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: A BSc (Hons) in Computer Science at NTU offers various opportunities for students to gain real-world experience and enhance their career prospects. These include work placements, live industry briefings, and research projects. Students can also benefit from the support of industry veterans across sectors such as Fujitsu Systems and the US Department of Homeland Security.

question: What are some of the diverse job roles that recent graduates from our Computer Science program have secured at various companies?
contexts:
["Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student."]
ground_truth: Recent graduates from our Computer Science program have secured a wide variety of job roles including Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, Graduate Game Development and Programmer, Software Engineer, Cyber Security Analyst, and Product Consultant at companies such as Next Retail Ltd, Boots UK, Cisco Systems, Schlumberger, Experian, BT, Rockstar Games, Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd, American Express, and the UK Government.

question: What is the nature of postgraduate courses offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU, and how do they prepare students for their chosen fields?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: The postgraduate courses offered by the Department of Computer Science at NTU are designed to be industrially relevant with a balance of theory and practice. They provide an outstanding environment for learning and development, combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment. The British Computing Society (BCS) has accredited all undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council, which also reflects on the postgraduate courses.

question: What role does the Interactive Systems Research Group play in utilizing artificial intelligence for cognitive and physical rehabilitation?
contexts:
['Centre for Computer Science and Informatics (CIRC)
        Harnessing enabling technologies ranging from machine learning, AI, and advanced display technologies, to intelligent sensors and robotics to drive advances for individuals and society.

Research groups

Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
        The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world.

Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA)
        This research group brings together academics researching in the areas of computational intelligence applications.

Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group (CCBI) 
        This research group is centred around brain research, mainly brain computer interfacing (BCI) including EEG hyper scanning, and body sensor networking (BCI).']
ground_truth: The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on developing new technologies that leverage enabling technologies such as AI, intelligent sensors, and robotics. These technologies are aimed at the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within real-world settings.

question:
What job roles have graduates from the Department of Computer Science at NTU secured, and how does the industry-focused nature of their courses contribute to this success?"

context: The Department of Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) is known for its strong emphasis on practical skills and real-world applications. Graduates from this department have been successful in securing a variety of job roles across different industries, including software development, data science, cybersecurity, and more. The industry-focused nature of the courses at NTU ensures that students gain hands-on experience through work placements, live industry briefs, and research projects, which enhances their employability and career prospects in the field of computer science.
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you.", "Careers in Computer Science

The industry-focused nature of our courses ensures you stand out from the crowd when it comes to job applications and pursuing your future career. Our graduates are widely respected amongst employers and are perceived as having a competitive edge due to the hands-on approach of our teaching.

Our recent graduates have secured roles at companies including:

Next Retail Ltd

Boots UK

Cisco Systems

Schlumberger

Experian

BT

Rockstar Games

Worldwide Clinical Trials UK Ltd

American Express

UK Government

They have gone into a wide variety of job roles including:

Business Analyst

Programmer

Project Software Implementation Officer

Web Developer

Games Tester

Graduate Game Development and Programmer

Software Engineer

Cyber Security Analyst

Product Consultant

Explore Computer Science

Find out about the facilities you'll have access to on your course and the benefits and support you'll receive as an NTU student."]
ground_truth: Graduates from the Department of Computer Science at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) have secured job roles such as Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, Graduate Game Development and Programmer, Software Engineer, and Cyber Security Analyst. The industry-focused nature of their courses contributes to this success by providing students with hands-on experience through work placements, live industry briefs, and research projects, which enhances their employability and career prospects in the field of computer science.

question: What is the significance of NTU's Department of Computer Science courses being accredited towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status by the Engineering Council?
contexts:
['Home

Study

Academic Schools

Science and Technology

Department of Computer Science

Department of Computer Science

Welcome to the Department of Computer Science at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Our undergraduate and postgraduate courses are designed to be industrially relevant with the right balance of theory and practice. The British Computing Society (BCS) have accredited all of our undergraduate degrees to Chartered IT Professional (CITP) status, and towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status with the Engineering Council. We are a thriving department combining expertise with modern facilities and equipment to create an outstanding environment for learning and development.']
ground_truth: The significance of NTU's Department of Computer Science courses being accredited towards Chartered Engineer (CEng) status by the Engineering Council lies in its validation of the quality and relevance of the education provided. This accreditation ensures that graduates are equipped with industry-relevant skills, theoretical knowledge, and practical experience necessary to excel as professionals in their field. It also enhances employability prospects for students, as CEng status is recognized by employers globally.

question: What role do external businesses and organizations play in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution?
contexts:
['The strength and relevance of our teaching and research are underpinned by a healthy synergy with a network of external businesses and organisations. We have over 200 industrial placement partners, including Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander and Refinitiv.

Research activity within the department is wide-ranging and collaborations and funding for research have been gained from a variety of sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security and the EU. Our research is internationally recognised, particularly in the areas of serious games, computational intelligence and security.

Meet the team']
ground_truth: External businesses and organizations play a crucial role in supporting the strength and relevance of teaching and research at this institution by providing industrial placement opportunities, collaborations, and funding. With over 200 industrial placement partners such as Microsoft, GlaxoSmithKline, IBM, Schlumberger, HP, Santander, and Refinitiv, students gain practical experience in their fields of study. Additionally, research activities are supported by various sources including Innovate UK, the EPSRC, the US Department of Homeland Security, and the EU, which contribute to a wide range of internationally recognized areas such as serious games, computational intelligence, and security.

question: What features and resources are available at the Clifton Campus for students studying Computer Science?
contexts:
["- BSc (Hons)

About Computer Science

From artificial intelligence to game technology, our courses span the whole spectrum of computer science.

You’ll study in state-of-the-art facilities at our Clifton Campus, which includes a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security, and human-interactive technology labs. It’s a self-contained campus with all the mod cons and equipment you might need.

You can count on the support of industry veterans from across the sector – from Fujitsu Systems to the US Department of Homeland Security. You can apply your learning to work placements, live industry briefs and research projects, as you gain real-world experience and enhance your career prospects in computing.

Learn more about Computer Science at NTU

Discover the inspiring story behind Hannah's decision to pursue Computer Science at NTU. Look through other videos for an insightful tour of our facilities and get a glimpse into the enriching academic journey that awaits you."]
ground_truth: The Clifton Campus offers state-of-the-art facilities for computer science students, including a robot arena, games consoles, networking and security labs, as well as human-interactive technology labs. It is a self-contained campus with modern amenities to support the learning experience.

question: What role does robotics play in the research conducted by the Computing and Informatics Research Centre's Centre for Computer Science and Informatics?
contexts:
['Centre for Computer Science and Informatics (CIRC)
        Harnessing enabling technologies ranging from machine learning, AI, and advanced display technologies, to intelligent sensors and robotics to drive advances for individuals and society.

Research groups

Interactive Systems Research Group (ISRG)
        The Interactive Systems Research Group focuses on the development of new technologies for the cognitive and physical rehabilitation of users within the real world.

Computational Intelligence and Applications Research Group (CIA)
        This research group brings together academics researching in the areas of computational intelligence applications.

Cognitive Computing and Brain Informatics Research Group (CCBI) 
        This research group is centred around brain research, mainly brain computer interfacing (BCI) including EEG hyper scanning, and body sensor networking (BCI).']

ground_truth: Industry-focused courses in Computer Science provide several advantages for job applications, including standing out from other candidates due to their practical approach and relevance to real-world employers. Graduates of these programs are perceived as having a competitive edge because they have hands-on experience that is highly valued by companies. This focus on industry also prepares students for various roles such as Business Analyst, Programmer, Project Software Implementation Officer, Web Developer, Games Tester, and more.

question: How does CSRG's work influence NTU's REF 2021 evaluation?
contexts:
["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

Find out more about our research

Our facilities

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]

["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]

question: What beginner-level computing courses are offered in the S&T school?
contexts:
['Zoheir Ezziane
            
            
                
                Senior Lecturer

View all staff

Computer Science courses

If you’re just starting out and are passionate about working in computing and technology, our accredited undergraduate computing courses can help your get there.

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.']

question: How does CSRG's work influence NTU's REF 2021 evaluation?
contexts:
["Cyber Security Research Group (CSRG)
        The cyber security research group (CSRG) is a dynamic team of seasoned professionals dedicated to researching and implementing effective solutions to safeguard against cyber threats.

Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021

In the latest Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2021, 86% of NTU's research impact was assessed to be either world-leading or internationally excellent. The overall quality of each Unit of Assessment NTU submitted to REF in 2021 also saw an improvement from the previous REF in 2014.

Find out more about REF 2021

Find out more about our research

Our facilities

With over £8 million invested, our computer science students will study in facilities designed to very high specifications with a variety of electronic and communication laboratories."]

question: Where's the top CS labs at NTU located?
contexts:
['Department of Computer Science
        Welcome to the Computer Science Department at NTU. The department combines internationally significant research with an outstanding record for teaching excellence. Our state-of-the-art facilities and career-focused approach to course design provide the right conditions for students to succeed in their chosen fields.

Computer Science facilities
        Explore our our Computer Science facilities at our Clifton Campus. You can take a look at the outstanding lab facilities in our ISTeC building.

Take a virtual tour
        The NTU virtual tour is a great way to get to know our University from the comfort of your own home.

question:
Title: Exploring the Impact of Physical Activity on Hormonal Regulation Through Wearable Technology Insights

Introduction:
The intricate relationship between physical activity and endocrine function has long been a subject of scientific exploration. The hormonal changes triggered by exercise play an essential role in maintaining homeostasis, growth, stress response, and overall well-being. Recent advancements in wearable technology have paved the way for more precise monitoring of these physiological responses during physical activity. This report delves into the effects of various exercises on endocrine function, drawing insights from recent seminars at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) and discussions about wearable tech's role in tracking exercise-induced hormonal changes.

Literature Review:
The Physical Activity and the Endocrine System 2024 seminar provided a comprehensive examination of how different types of physical activity influence endocrine function, including stress response and growth hormone release (Context1). Additionally, the collaboration between NTU's Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter highlighted the potential for wearable technology to revolutionize our understanding of these processes by offering real-time data on physiological responses during exercise (Context2).

Methodology:
To analyze recent research findings, this report reviews studies presented at both events. The methodologies employed in these studies include longitudinal monitoring using wearable devices and laboratory analyses to measure hormone levels before, during, and after physical activity. By synthesizing data from various sources, we aim to identify patterns and correlations between exercise intensity, duration, type, and endocrine responses.

Results and Discussion:
The seminar at NTU revealed that moderate-intensity aerobic exercises have a significant impact on reducing stress hormones like cortisol while promoting the release of growth hormone (GH). The discussion with IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter emphasized how wearable technology can provide continuous, non-invasive monitoring of these changes. For instance, heart rate variability and sweat analysis from wearables have been correlated with GH secretion during exercise.

Conclusion:
Advancements in wearable technology offer promising opportunities to deepen our understanding of the complex relationship between physical activity and endocrine function. By leveraging real-time data, researchers can better comprehend how different types of exercises affect hormonal balance, ultimately leading to more personalized exercise recommendations for optimal health outcomes.

References:
1. [Insert relevant studies from the Physical Activity and Endocrine System 2024 seminar]
2. [Insert relevant studies on wearable technology's role in monitoring endocrine responses during exercise, as discussed by NTU Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter]

question:
Title: Exploring the Impact of Physical Activity on Hormonal Regulation Through Wearable Technology Insights

Introduction:
The intricate relationship between physical activity and endocrine function has long been a subject of scientific exploration. The hormonal changes triggered by exercise play an essential role in maintaining homeostasis, growth, stress response, and overall well-being. Recent advancements in wearable technology have paved the way for more precise monitoring of these physiological responses during physical activity. This report delves into the effects of various exercises on endocrine function, drawing insights from recent seminars at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) and discussions about wearable tech's role in tracking exercise-induced hormonal changes.

Literature Review:
The Physical Activity and the Endocrine System 2024 seminar provided a comprehensive examination of how different types of physical activity influence endocrine function, including stress response and growth hormone release (Context1). Additionally, the collaboration between NTU's Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter highlighted the potential for wearable technology to revolutionize our understanding of these processes by offering real-time data on physiological responses during exercise (Context2).

Methodology:
To analyze recent research findings, this report reviews studies presented at both events. The methodologies employed in these studies include longitudinal monitoring using wearable devices and laboratory analyses to measure hormone levels before, during, and after physical activity. By synthesizing data from various sources, we aim to identify patterns and correlations between exercise intensity, duration, type, and endocrine responses.

Results and Discussion:
The seminar at NTU revealed that moderate-intensity aerobic exercises have a significant impact on reducing stress hormones like cortisol while promoting the release of growth hormone (GH). The discussion with IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter emphasized how wearable technology can provide continuous, non-invasive monitoring of these changes. For instance, heart rate variability and sweat analysis from wearables have been correlated with GH secretion during exercise.

Conclusion:
Advancements in wearable technology offer promising opportunities to deepen our understanding of the complex relationship between physical activity and endocrine function. By leveraging real-time data, researchers can better comprehend how different types of exercises affect hormonal balance, ultimately leading to more personalized exercise recommendations for optimal health outcomes.

References:
1. [Insert relevant studies from the Physical Activity and Endocrine System 2024 seminar]
2. [Insert relevant studies on wearable technology's role in monitoring endocrine responses during exercise, as discussed by NTU Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter]

question:
Title: Exploring the Impact of Physical Activity on Hormonal Regulation Through Wearable Technology Insights

Introduction:
The intricate relationship between physical activity and endocrine function has long been a subject of scientific exploration. The hormonal changes triggered by exercise play an essential role in maintaining homeostasis, growth, stress response, and overall well-being. Recent advancements in wearable technology have paved the way for more precise monitoring of these physiological responses during physical activity. This report delves into the effects of various exercises on endocrine function, drawing insights from recent seminars at Nottingham Trent University (NTU) and discussions about wearable tech's role in tracking exercise-induced hormonal changes.

Literature Review:
The Physical Activity and the Endocrine System 2024 seminar provided a comprehensive examination of how different types of physical activity influence endocrine function, including stress response and growth hormone release (Context1). Additionally, the collaboration between NTU's Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter highlighted the potential for wearable technology to revolutionize our understanding of these processes by offering real-time data on physiological responses during exercise (Context2).

Methodology:
To analyze recent research findings, this report reviews studies presented at both events. The methodologies employed in these studies include longitudinal monitoring using wearable devices and laboratory analyses to measure hormone levels before, during, and after physical activity. By synthesizing data from various sources, we aim to identify patterns and correlations between exercise intensity, duration, type, and endocrine responses.

Results and Discussion:
The seminar at NTU revealed that moderate-intensity aerobic exercises have a significant impact on reducing stress hormones like cortisol while promoting the release of growth hormone (GH). The discussion with IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter emphasized how wearable technology can provide continuous, non-invasive monitoring of these changes. For instance, heart rate variability and sweat analysis from wearables have been correlated with GH secretion during exercise.

Conclusion:
Advancements in wearable technology offer promising opportunities to deepen our understanding of the complex relationship between physical activity and endocrine function. By leveraging real-time data, researchers can better comprehend how different types of exercises affect hormonal balance, ultimately leading to more personalized exercise recommendations for optimal health outcomes.

References:
1. [Insert relevant studies from the Physical Activity and Endocrine System 2024 seminar]
2. [Insert relevant studies on wearable technology's role in monitoring endocrine responses during exercise, as discussed by NTU Department of Engineering and IEEE Nanotechnology Chapter]

question: How does Zoheir Ezziane support digital tech progress at SST through CIRC involvement?
contexts:
['Zoheir Ezziane
            
            
                
                Senior Lecturer
                
            
            
              
                
                    
                
            
            
                        
                
                    
                    School of Science & Technology

View all staff

Computer Science courses

If you’re just starting out and are passionate about working in computing and technology, our accredited undergraduate computing courses can help your get there.

View our courses

Our research

The Computing and Informatics Research Centre’s (CIRC) unifying and overarching research vision is ‘Enabling Digital Technology’ and is grounded in high-quality, interdisciplinary work with expertise in advanced computer science topics with links to partners from both academia and industry. The CIRC’s research is delivered by four groups.']
